Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, alleging that Defendant Linda Martinez failed to address hazardous mold conditions in Plaintiff Sarah Thompson’s apartment at 123 Maple Street, Lowell, MA, causing harm to Plaintiff’s health and property and interfering with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her rental unit.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 218, \u00a.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $25,000.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, \u00a.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, § 1, because the property at issue is located in Lowell, MA, and both parties reside or conduct business within this Court’s jurisdiction.

Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.raw_text: Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.
Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is further contrary to the protections set forth in the Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., which requires landlords to maintain rental units in a habitable condition and free from conditions that are harmful to occupants’ health.

105 CMR 410.602.proposition: The Massachusetts Sanitary Code expressly requires rental units to be free of conditions that endanger the health of occupants. See 105 CMR 410.602.

*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Indus., Inc.*,.proposition: In *Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Indus., Inc.*, 427 Mass. 1 (1998), the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court affirmed that a landlord’s failure to remedy harmful conditions may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment if it substantially interferes with a tenant’s use of the premises.
*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Indus., Inc.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Industries concerns handicap discrimination and the prima facie standard under G.L. c. 151B § 4(16) in an employment-termination context. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or a landlord’s failure to remedy harmful conditions. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on unremedied conditions.
*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Indus., Inc.*,.relevant_excerpt: "We clarify today the prima facie standard a plaintiff must meet to establish liability in a case involving a claim of handicap discrimination in violation of G. L. c. 151B, § 4 (16). The defendant, Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc. (Mass.) (BFI), appeals from a jury verdict that it unlawfully fired the plaintiff, Brian A. Dartt, because of a handicap, an earlier work-related injury to his back."

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: In similar mold-related cases, Massachusetts courts have recognized the duty of landlords to remediate hazardous conditions promptly.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion involves severe habitability defects (heat, hot water, vermin, code violations) but does not mention mold or mold-related health conditions. It recognizes a landlord’s liability for failing to repair known sanitary, building, and fire code violations and discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment, but it does not specifically address mold or a distinct duty to remediate mold promptly. Using this case as authority for mold-specific remediation duties would therefore be inaccurate and overbroad, even though its general landlord-duty principles could be analogized.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment exists to protect tenants from unreasonable interferences, including conditions that impact health, safety, and the basic enjoyment of their homes. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court extensively discusses the statutory and common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from serious interferences with the tenancy, grounded in sanitary and safety-related conditions in the home. It ties G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment to unsanitary flooding conditions that impair the tenant’s ability to live in the apartment, recognizing such interferences as within the scope of quiet enjoyment and allowing recovery for resulting personal (including emotional) injuries. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant exists to protect tenants from unreasonable interferences affecting health, safety, and basic enjoyment of their homes.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. … These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes.”

*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 (1.proposition: A landlord’s failure to act when notified of hazardous conditions may also result in liability for consequential damages, including health-related harms. See *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 (1979).
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that a landlord can be liable in tort for personal injuries resulting from defects in premises under the landlord’s control or from breach of an implied warranty of code compliance. However, the discussed liability is not framed around a failure to act after being notified of hazardous conditions, nor does it focus on health-related consequential damages (like illness) as opposed to direct physical injury from a structural defect. General Laws c. 186, § 19 (the notice-based statute) is quoted in a footnote, but the holding does not turn on notice or consequential health harms, so the case does not squarely support the specific proposition stated.
*Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443 (1.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord or lessor of any real estate except an owner-occupied two-or three-family dwelling shall, within a reasonable time following receipt of a written notice from a tenant forwarded by registered or certified mail of an unsafe condition…exercise reasonable care to correct the unsafe condition described in said notice… The tenant or any person rightfully on said premises injured as a result of the failure to correct said unsafe condition within a reasonable time shall have a right of action in tort against the landlord or lessor for damages.” (G. L. c. 186, § 19, quoted at *448.)

*Manzaro v. McCann*, 401 Mass. 113 (1987.proposition: Emotional distress damages are available in actions for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Manzaro v. McCann*, 401 Mass. 113 (1987).
*Manzaro v. McCann*, 401 Mass. 113 (1987.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case concerning rape and indecent assault and battery, focusing on prosecutorial argument, jury instructions, scienter under G.L. c. 265, § 13F, and duplicative convictions. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or damages for emotional distress. Therefore, this case cannot be authority for the proposition that emotional distress damages are available for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a tenant may recover actual damages, punitive damages, and attorneys’ fees for violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See also *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) and explicitly states the remedies available to tenants upon a violation, including damages, injunctive relief, costs, and reasonable attorneys’ fees. While the opinion focuses on liability rather than quantifying "actual" versus "punitive" damages, § 14 itself provides for multiple damages (which Massachusetts decisions describe as punitive in nature) and the court here reaffirms that tenants may obtain damages and attorneys’ fees under this statute. Thus, the case supports citing § 14 as authorizing actual damages, punitive (multiple) damages, and attorneys’ fees for violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. This section also confers on the Superior and District Courts the authority in equity to restrain violations of its provisions. … If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.
